executive_summary: City council adopted Downtown Overlay District with increased affordable housing (15%), restored parking (1.25/unit), new green building standards, and 8-story height limit on Main Street. Emergency water main repair authorized ($1.2M). New health impact assessment ordinance introduced for industrial developments.

what_changed.change: Downtown Overlay District adopted with affordable housing requirement increased from 10% to 15% for developments over 20 units
Parking requirement set at 1.25 spaces per unit (compromise between original 1.5 and proposed 1.0)
New mandatory green building standards — LEED Silver equivalent or higher for all new construction in overlay district
Height limit increased from 6 to 8 stories for parcels fronting Main Street
New Health Impact Assessment requirement introduced for industrial developments over 25,000 sq ft (first reading)
Emergency water main repair authorized — $1.2M from Water Enterprise Fund for critical 36-inch main beneath Riverside Boulevard
$500K state DOT grant accepted for bicycle infrastructure including protected bike lanes and bike share pilot

deadlines.item: Downtown Overlay District effective date (30 days after adoption)
Health Impact Assessment ordinance second reading
Emergency water main repair — 8-12 weeks from procurement start
Warehouse District comprehensive report to council (May meeting)

action_checklist.action: Review updated Downtown Overlay District requirements — 15% affordable housing, 1.25 parking ratio, LEED Silver standard
Prepare for potential water service disruptions — 72-hour advance notice expected for affected areas near Riverside Boulevard
Track Health Impact Assessment ordinance second reading on March 4 if operating industrial facilities near residential zones
Existing commercial tenants in overlay district should review 18-month relocation assistance provisions
Monitor warehouse district environmental review — community input sessions Feb 22 and Mar 8

risk_flags.flag: Height increase may impact adjacent residential neighborhoods
risk_flags.why: The increase from 6 to 8 stories on Main Street parcels was contested (2 opposing votes). CM Williams raised neighborhood impact concerns that were not fully addressed.
36-inch water main from 1978 has critical corrosion at three joints. Serves 8,500 connections. Emergency declaration indicates imminent failure risk.
Traffic study delayed from March to April 2026. Comprehensive report pushed to May. Expanded scope adds complexity but also adds $45K economic analysis cost.
